Background: The Movin and Bonar scoring systems are established methods for classifying histopathological findings in tendinopathy. This study aimed to compare the reliability of these two scoring systems in evaluating tendon tissue. Methods: In this randomised controlled trial, tendon samples were obtained from 88 individuals (49 men, 39 women; mean age, 58.2 years) undergoing arthroscopic rotator cuff repair and five male patients (mean age, 69.6 years) who died of cardiovascular events. A piece of supraspinatus tendon not directly involved in the tear was harvested. Hematoxylin and eosin staining and Alcian blue were used to assess slides with Bonar and Movin scores. The primary outcome was the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) between the two scoring systems, measured immediately post-surgery. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. Outcome assessors were blinded to the scoring system used. Results: The ICC was 0.921 (95% CI 0.790â€“0.963), indicating high reliability between the scoring systems. No adverse events were reported. Interpretation: The high correlation between Movin and Bonar scores suggests both are reliable for histopathological evaluation in tendinopathy, assessing similar characteristics and variables of tendon abnormalities. This supports their use in clinical and research settings for consistent evaluation of tendon pathology. Trial registration: [Trial registration number]. Funding: [Source of funding].
